policy_name: Artificial Intelligence Policy for Students and Faculty

scope.jurisdiction: All MIT courses and research activities

purpose: To establish clear expectations for the responsible use of AI tools in academic work while fostering innovation and technological literacy.

allowed_uses.description: Using AI to generate research ideas, explore problem spaces, and identify novel approaches
examples: Using ChatGPT to brainstorm research questions
Using Copilot to explore algorithm design approaches
Using Claude to identify gaps in literature

allowed_uses.description: Using AI to write, refactor, test, and debug code with human oversight
examples: Using GitHub Copilot for code generation with review
Using ChatGPT to debug error messages
Using AI to generate unit tests
allowed_uses.disclosure_method: Code comment with AI tool name and version

allowed_uses.description: Using AI to analyze datasets, identify patterns, and create visualizations
examples: Using AI to generate statistical analysis code
Using AI to suggest visualization approaches
Using AI to interpret data patterns

allowed_uses.description: Using AI to improve clarity, grammar, and organization while maintaining authentic voice
examples: Using Grammarly AI for proofreading
Using AI for structure suggestions
Using AI to improve clarity of technical writing

allowed_uses.description: Using AI as a tutor to understand concepts and course material
examples: Using AI to explain difficult concepts
Using AI to work through practice problems
Using AI to clarify technical terminology

allowed_uses.description: Using AI to summarize papers, identify themes, and organize references
examples: Using AI to summarize academic papers
Using AI to identify related work
Using AI to organize citations

prohibited_uses.use_case: Submitting AI-Generated Work as Your Own
prohibited_uses.description: Passing off AI output as original human work without attribution
examples: Submitting AI-written essay without disclosure
Turning in AI-generated code as own work
Submitting AI-generated data analysis
prohibited_uses.consequence: Academic integrity violation - failing grade, disciplinary hearing

prohibited_uses.description: Using AI to complete work that violates individual assignment requirements
examples: Using AI on take-home exam marked as 'no AI allowed'
Using AI when collaboration is prohibited
Using AI to circumvent learning objectives
prohibited_uses.consequence: Failing grade for assignment or course

prohibited_uses.description: Using AI to generate plagiarism, misinformation, or harmful material
examples: Using AI to create convincing false data
Using AI to generate biased or discriminatory content
Using AI to fabricate research findings
prohibited_uses.consequence: Academic integrity violation, potential legal action

prohibited_uses.description: Using AI tools in exam proctoring or other controlled assessment situations
examples: Using AI during proctored exams
Using AI in laboratory assessments
Using AI during in-class quizzes

disclosure_requirements.when_required: Any substantive use of AI tools in academic work

formats.example: # Used GitHub Copilot v1.88 to generate sorting algorithm - 2025-01-10

formats.template: The [description] was generated using [Tool Name]. All outputs were reviewed and modified for accuracy.
formats.example: The statistical analysis was generated using ChatGPT-4. All calculations were verified and modified for accuracy.

formats.template: AI Tool Usage Statement: [list all tools and their purposes]
formats.example: AI Tool Usage Statement: GitHub Copilot (code generation, debugging), ChatGPT-4 (concept explanation), Grammarly (proofreading)

evaluating_ai_use: Assess whether AI use enhances learning or circumvents it
Verify that disclosure is accurate and complete
Check that AI output was appropriately reviewed and modified
Ensure learning objectives were still achieved
red_flags: AI output that appears unreviewed or unmodified
Disclosure missing for clearly AI-generated content
Content that violates academic integrity standards

enforcement.responsible_office: Dean of Undergraduate Education / Graduate School Dean
enforcement.reporting: Reports of suspected violations should be submitted to [department head]
enforcement.process: Follows standard MIT academic integrity investigation process
enforcement.appeals: Appeals process available per MIT regulations

frequently_asked_questions.question: Can I use ChatGPT to write my problem set solutions?
frequently_asked_questions.answer: No. You should use AI as a learning tool to understand concepts, but must write your own solutions. Any code or solutions generated by AI must be disclosed and substantially rewritten.

frequently_asked_questions.question: Is it okay to use GitHub Copilot for programming assignments?
frequently_asked_questions.answer: Yes, with disclosure and review. You must disclose its use and verify all generated code works correctly and is appropriately modified.

frequently_asked_questions.question: Can I use AI on my research paper?
frequently_asked_questions.answer: You can use AI for brainstorming, structure suggestions, and proofreading. You must disclose any substantive AI assistance and maintain the authenticity of your own analysis and conclusions.
